NewWords.WordPhrase: n. well-lit workroom of a painter, a photographer, etc. 画室；照相室；工作室
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She was in her studio again, painting onto a large canvas.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  菊苣
n. （一道）生菜； 色拉
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. a salad of tomato, onion and cucumber

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 主教
n. 衣袖
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. His sleeves were rolled up to his elbows.

NewWords.WordPhrase: 灯笼袖
harmonious(ly) 和谐的（地）
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. It was just an ordinary voice, but he sang in tune.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. held or done by two or more persons together 共同的；共有的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She had taken the money out of the joint account she had with her husband.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 肺炎
v.  (of an evil force)move through(a place)in a threatening way; move quietly and cautiously in order to get near 可怕地蔓延或游荡（于）；潜行，偷偷接近
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. When night falls, danger stalks the streets of the city.

NewWords.WordPhrase: in various places 各处
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. During the summer vacation he will do a bit of teaching here and there.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a.  very cold, like ice 极冷的；冰冷的
n. person, animal, etc. suffering death, injury or loss 牺牲者；受害的人（或动物等）
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Police and hospital records indicate that the majority of victims of domestic violence are women.

NewWords.WordPhrase: ad.  not quite; almost not 几乎没有；几乎不   scarce a. not plentiful; rare 不充足的；难得的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I can scarcely remember when I last ate home-baked bread.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 门厅, 过道
a. growing thickly; thick and rough 密生的；丛生的  bushy hair
n.  arch of hair above the eye 眉毛
n. ,int.  nonsense 胡说；无意义的话
n. （四轮）载人马车
vt. take (a number, quantity) away from 减去；扣除
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Passenger cars can be added or subtracted at either end of the subway train.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a.  able to cure illness 能治病的   a curative herb
a.  happy; cheerful; bright and gay 高兴的；愉快的；欢乐的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. From the other room, we could hear the merry sound of laughter and glasses clinking.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. (pl.) sheets, blanket, etc. for a bed 床上用品
ad. with the back or end first 倒着
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The helicopter can travel forward, backward, or sideways.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. without covering, clothing, or decoration 光秃秃的；裸露的；无装饰的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Soil held in place by plant roots is less likely to blow or wash away than bare soil.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. dull; gloomy; causing low spirits 沉闷的；阴沉的；使人忧郁的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. By the time they had waited five hours for their delayed flight, everyone looked dreary.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 常春藤
n. 藤，藤本植物；攀缘植物
in a low voice 低声地
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He bent down and addressed her in a whisper.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. foolish talk, ideas, behavior 废话；荒唐的念头；愚蠢的行为
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I think the report is nonsense and nothing but a waste of paper.

NewWords.WordPhrase: allow (sth.) to be free of control 放手，放纵
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The sick whale will be taken care of by the scientists before being turned loose.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  man who works in a mine 矿工
n.  person who paints pictures; artist 画图者；画家
n. 胡须
have an appearance for a particular job, role, or position 看上去很像
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I think he must be a captain -- he certainly looks the part.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 杜松子酒
to an extreme degree 过度
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. His father never smoked or drank to excess.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. a piece of work, esp. art, which is the best of its type or the best a person has done（尤指艺术品）杰作； 代表作
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn is considered Mark Twain's masterpiece.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. easily damaged or broken; not strong and healthy 易碎的；虚弱的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The thin glass is fragile.

NewWords.WordPhrase: as regards other matters 至于其它
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The book contains some interesting passages about the author's childhood. For the rest, it is rather dull.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a.  violent and angry 凶猛的；愤怒的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. It was estimated that the fierce storm killed at least several thousand people and left more than one million without homes.

NewWords.WordPhrase: v. ridicule; make fun of 嘲弄；取笑
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. They mocked him and called him a coward.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. lack in strength and determination 软弱；意志不坚定
ad.  暗淡地；模糊不清地   dim a.
n. （油画）画布
n.  画架
n. sth. imagined; unfounded opinion or belief 幻想，幻觉；胡思乱想
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The forecasts in his book were not wild fancies.

NewWords.WordPhrase: v. move in a continuous flow, pour out 流，淌；涌
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The river streamed past my house.

NewWords.WordPhrase: be told about or have knowledge of 听说，得知
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Three weeks passed, and nothing was heard of the missing boy.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. continuing; occurring again and again 持续的；一再发生的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The persistent growth of the EU countries has been remarkable.

NewWords.WordPhrase: v. mix 混合
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The singer's style mingles jazz and country music.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. turned upside down 翻转的，倒着放的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He clung to the upturned boat, screaming for help.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 烧水用的壶
ad.  tiredly 疲倦地；劳累地   weary a.
int. look; see 看，瞧
be easily seen above or among others 显著；突出
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The working experience in Microsoft last year still stands out in my mind.

NewWords.WordPhrase: (of time) pass gradually; (cause to) become thin or damaged by constant use （时间）流逝；磨损，磨去
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. They didn't reach an agreement. Instead they wore the afternoon away in arguing.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. faint light after sunset; the time just before night 暮色；黄昏
a. solitary; without companion 孤独的；孤单的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He was shot by a lone gunman.

NewWords.WordPhrase: (clung) vi. hold tight; resist separation 抓紧；抱紧  cling to hold tight to 紧紧抓住（或抱住）
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The child is clinging to his mother's legs.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. showing no mercy 无慈悲心的；无怜悯心的
attract the attention of (sb.) by speaking out 呼唤
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The fisherman called to the villagers on the shore.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 煤气；天然气
n. 炉；火炉；暖炉
n. 带手柄的小镜子
n. 枕头
坐起来
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The teacher asked his students to sit up straight.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. (of diseases) coming quickly to the critical stage; severe 急性的；严重的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She was taken to the hospital suffering from acute appendicitis.

NewWords.WordPhrase: be wet all over 湿透的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Their house was flooded: the carpet was wet through and the furniture was ruined.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 灯笼
n. 调色板
v. (cause to) move about in a quick, irregular way 飘动，晃动
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The ugly duckling fluttered into the milk-pan, and splashed the milk about the room.
